Fuel Adjustment Clauses and Good Public Policy (UtiliPoint.com - May 14, 2007)



UtiliPoint.com - May 14, 2007 - Even though the roots of electric fuel adjustment clauses (FAC) go back to World War I, they became prominent again in the 1970s with the OPEC oil price shock.

The Greening of Corporate America (EnergyBiz Insider - May 14, 2007)



EnergyBiz Insider - May 14, 2007 - Exelon Corp.'s environmental positions are paying off. The Chicago-based utility has retrofitted its headquarters so as to comply with green standards for commercial office buildings -- a move that is winning accolades from all corners.

NATIONAL NEWS






Wateree Dam crisis plan gets an update: Officials nail down specifics in case it fails after natural disaster or terrorist



May 14--Kershaw County is updating an emergency preparedness plan that it will use if the Wateree Dam breaks.  The new plan, to be completed in two to three months, will provide detailed job descriptions for each official, update shelter locations and evacuation routes and prepare for the worst-case scenario -- a total failure of the dam. The Wateree Dam impounds the 13,864-acre Lake Wateree. ...


May 14, 2007 Knight Ridder Tribune Business News



Lowcost power going up for grabs while officials sit back: WNY representatives fail to push for cheap electricity



May 13--About 15 percent of the electricity produced by the Niagara Power Project is up for grabs this summer, the first time in years, perhaps decades, that so much has been in play.  But local officials, starting with the delegation that represents Western New York in the State Legislature, are doing little to seize the opportunity. "We ought to be at work on this stuff," Rep.


May 13, 2007 Knight Ridder Tribune Business News



A good old thumping for fuel bills



May 13--Going green can save your company money as well as help the planet.  The Carbon Trust believes that most firms can slash 20 per cent off their energy bills without dipping into their pockets. The Government-backed body provides free advice and will visit premises to offer tips. It also provides interest-free loans for investing in eco-friendly work solutions.


May 13, 2007 Knight Ridder Tribune Business News



Companies announce pact with FutureGen



May 13--TXU Corp. and Texas Energy Future Holdings recently announced a $1 million commitment to support the state's bid for the FutureGen power plant. Leon County and Odessa are among four sites under consideration for the plant. The other two are in Illinois. The FutureGen Alliance is a non-profit consortium of companies supporting FutureGen, the U.S. Department of Energy project intended to ...


May 13, 2007 Knight Ridder Tribune Business News



Progress Energy investing $2.5 million in upgrades for siren system



May 13--Hartsville residents have begun hearing the sounds of Progress -- Energy, that is.  Progress Energy is investing $2.5 million in upgrades to the siren system in the Emergency Planning Zone (EPZ) surrounding the H.B. Robinson Nuclear Plant. Andy Cole, communications specialist at the Robinson plant, said the changes are simply an upgrade to the current siren system being used by the plant. ...


May 13, 2007 Knight Ridder Tribune Business News



A first look at flood devastation



May 14--MISSOURI VALLEY, Iowa -- Rachel and Ryan Rempel spotted their little red porch just after 2 p.m. Sunday.  It had broken off their house and floated into a field across the street. Inside their Missouri Valley home, floodwater left behind soggy carpet, moldy furniture and a foul, dank smell. The water had been a foot deep. The Rempels, along with many other residents of the Willow Creek ...


May 14, 2007 Knight Ridder Tribune Business News



Experts: Evidence of climate change can be found in southern Wisconsin



May 13--ROCK COUNTY  Farmer David Arndt knows the value of rain. Some of his corn crop shriveled and died during a searing drought in the summer of 1976. Almost 30 years ago, Arndt started installing irrigation as insurance against dry spells on his 2,500 acres. Last fall, his fertile fields in La Prairie Township produced a record average of 211 bushels of corn per acre.


May 13, 2007 Knight Ridder Tribune Business News



Akron utility to hold annual meeting: FirstEnergy has 3 items up for vote, opposes 3 shareholder proposals



May 13--FirstEnergy Corp. will hold its annual shareholders meeting Tuesday at the John S. Knight Center.  Shareholders are to vote on six proposals at the meeting, which will start at 10:30 a.m. The Akron-based utility recommends that shareholders approve three company-sponsored proposals and reject three shareholder proposals. The three company-sponsored proposals are: --Elect 11 members to the ...


May 13, 2007 Knight Ridder Tribune Business News





News you can use: Options trading signals moves in share prices



NEW YORK: Illegal or not, trading in options may be the most prescient news you can use. The number of options to buy shares of Valero Energy and American Express doubled in the week before the companies reported better-than-estimated earnings. Trading in contracts tied to TXU and Dow Jones climbed at least sevenfold a day ahead of takeover announcements that pushed the stocks up as much as 55 ...

Uranerz Acquires Additional Uranium Property Adjoining Nichols Ranch



Uranerz Energy Corporation (AMEX: URZ)(FRANKFURT: U9E) is pleased to announce the successful leasing of the fee mineral lands adjacent to and west of the Company's Nichols Ranch ISR uranium project. INTERNATIONAL NEWS







Wind Power Increased 19% In 2006



-- As the high-flying sector keeps enjoying powerful Chinese and U.S. demand, the wind energy market will grow by 19% per year through the end of the decade the Global Wind Energy Council said May 11. Even though that would mark a slowdown from the annual 24% growth registered in 2002-2006, the market would still double by the end of the decade, the Global Wind Energy Council said.

May 14, 2007 Internet Wire



Russia wins new natural gas deal, undermining rival U.S. plan



MOSCOW: Russia agreed to build a new pipeline to import more natural gas from Turkmenistan, bolstering its dominant hold on supplies to Europe and heading off a rival U.S.-backed plan that would bypass Russian territory. President Vladimir Putin of Russia met his counterparts from Turkmenistan and Kazakhstan on Saturday and reached a preliminary agreement on the pipeline, with a final accord ...


May 14, 2007 International Herald Tribune



Energy needs 'hobbled' by slow consents



The Government's call for more renewable energy is being hobbled by slow consent processes for wind farms, prompting Environment Minister David Benson-Pope to call in chief environment judge John Bollard to discuss the delays. The meeting comes as a row simmers between the Government and state generator Meridian over its planned 630-megawatt Project Hayes wind farm in Otago.
